units.title: Organoid Derivation from Tissue
units.text: Patient resection material is cut into small pieces, washed thoroughly and digested with collagenase. After additional washing and filtration, the digested tissue is plated in basement membrane extract (BME) and supplemented with expansion medium (Fig. 2b,c).
units.rationale: This is a clear, actionable step in the protocol for initiating organoid culture from tissue samples.

units.title: BME Plating for 3D Culture
units.text: BME, a gel-like substance that polymerizes at temperatures above 10 °C, is used to mimic the extracellular matrix and provide support for 3D organoids (Fig. 2d,e).
units.rationale: Describes a critical procedural step for creating the 3D environment necessary for organoid growth.

units.title: Organoid Passaging via Fragments
units.text: We describe both single-cell organoid passaging by trypsinization (Step 43A; Fig. 2g) and passaging via organoid fragments by mechanical disruption, referred to as shearing (Step 43B; Fig. 2g).
units.rationale: Provides specific, actionable method for maintaining organoid cultures through passaging.

units.title: Organoid Passaging via Single Cells
units.text: If you want to generate clonal organoid cultures after transfection, we recommend using an organoid culture that allows passaging via single cells.
units.rationale: Actionable instruction for achieving clonality, essential for genetic manipulation workflows.

units.title: Lipofectamine-Based Transfection
units.text: We discuss three different methods for genetically modifying breast organoids, including Lipofectamine 2000 for transient transfection with moderate-to-high efficiency (Step 65A),
units.rationale: Specific protocol step for genetic manipulation using a defined reagent and method.

units.title: Electroporation-Based Transfection
units.text: electroporation for transient transfection with high efficiency (Step 65B; used for Fig. S4 of ref. 7) or
units.rationale: Actionable procedure for genetic modification using electroporation with defined parameters.

units.title: Lentiviral Transduction
units.rationale: Direct instruction for a genetic manipulation technique with a specified step number.

units.title: Organoid Selection After Genetic Manipulation
units.text: Organoid selection Clone picking (CLONAL) SELECTION Selection agent Steps 66–68 Steps 69–77 10 min 1.5–2 h
units.rationale: Clear procedural steps for selecting genetically modified organoids after transfection or transduction.

units.title: Orthotopic Organoid Transplantation
units.text: Finally, we introduce an optimized method for orthotopic organoid transplantation in mice, which includes injection of organoids and estrogen pellets without the need for surgery.
units.rationale: Describes a key in vivo procedure with specific components and advantage over surgical methods.

units.title: Tissue Digestion Protocol
units.text: Add 500 µl of collagenase (20 mg/ml stock, final concentration 1 mg/ml) and 10 µl of ROCK inhibitor (10 mM stock, final concentration 10 µM) to the 50-ml Falcon tube containing the minced tissue. Wrap the 50-ml Falcon tube with Paraﬁlm and place the tube at a slight angle (~15°) on top of an orbital shaker located inside a heated incubator oven at 37 °C. Set the orbital shaker at 140 r.p.m. and digest the tissue for 1–2 h.
units.rationale: Detailed, step-by-step procedure for tissue digestion with precise reagents, conditions, and timing.
